messageBody:
weshdim@... scripsit:

> Once I realized I was reading American pronunciation, things fell into
> place. (My accent is Australian.)

This is a long-running debate on this list: whether to use the QS letters
to represent the writer's accent, or to use them in a generalized way to
represent (insofar as possible) all accents simultaneously, by making all
the distinctions that any living accent makes. Traditional orthography,
despite its innumerable faults, actually succeeds at this quite well:
it represents a roughly 14th-century pronunciation from which almost
all living accents are descended.

I say "insofar as possible" because QS fundamentally represents
conservative RP, with concessions to American accents in the matter of
"r". As a result, there are distinctions it cannot represent, most
notably the difference between "horse" and "hoarse" among those who
do not pronounce them the same. (Traditional orthography mostly nails
this one, with the usual depressing list of exceptions: "pork" would
be better spelled "poark", for example.)

In addition, there are three groups of words that vary fundamentally
between accents, the BATH set, the DANCE set, and the CLOTH set.
My personal view is that the first two groups should be written with
30 At and not 32 Ah, and the last with 34 Ox and not 33 Awe. This does
not represent my own pronunciation!

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
Nobody expects the RESTifarian Inquisition! Our chief weapon is
surprise ... surprise and tedium ... tedium and surprise ....
Our two weapons are tedium and surprise ... and ruthless disregard
for unpleasant facts.... Our three weapons are tedium, surprise, and
ruthless disregard ... and an almost fanatical devotion to Roy Fielding....
